name: C. Dora and C++
statement:
Dora has just learned the programming language C++!However, she has
completely misunderstood the meaning of C++. She considers it as two
kinds of adding operations on the array c with n elements. Dora has two
integers a and b. In one operation, she can choose one of the following
things to do. Choose an integer i such that 1
leq i
leq n, and increase c_i by a. Choose an integer i such that 1
leq i
leq n, and increase c_i by b. Note that a and b are , and they can be
the same.Let’s define a of array d as
max(d_i) -
min(d_i). For instance, the range of the array [1, 2, 3, 4] is 4 - 1 =
3, the range of the array [5, 2, 8, 2, 2, 1] is 8 - 1 = 7, and the range
of the array [3, 3, 3] is 3 - 3 = 0.After any number of operations
(possibly, 0), Dora calculates the range of the new array. You need to
help Dora minimize this value, but since Dora loves exploring all by
herself, you only need to tell her the minimized value.
solutions: #include <bits/stdc++.h>using namespace std; const int maxN = 110000;int c[maxN]; int main() {	ios::sync_with_stdio(0);	cin.tie(0); cout.tie(0);	int T;	for (cin >> T; T; T--) {		int n, a, b; cin >> n >> a >> b;		int g = __gcd(a, b);		for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {			cin >> c[i];			c[i] %= g;		}		sort(c, c + n);		int mn = c[n - 1] - c[0];		for (int i = 1; i < n; i++) {			mn = min(mn, c[i - 1] + g - c[i]);		}		cout << mn << '\n';	}	return 0;}
